com.obdobion.argument.annotation

Annotation Type Arg


  • @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Target(value=FIELD)
 @Repeatable(value=Args.class)
public @interface Arg
    "argument" is a full featured command line argument processor for Java. Essentially, it allows your program to get run-time direction from the user as they execute it on the command line. (Example: yourProgram --tail) This assumes that you have written a program called yourProgram and that it will need to do something special if the user also enters the --tail argument. "argument" is a library that makes handling this type of command line interaction very easy to implement. All parsers are equipped with a few basic arguments; --help, -?, -!, and @(filename).

    In the main method in your program, or somewhere similar, 

     public static void main (final String[] args) {
     MyProgram instance = new MyProgram();
    and process the command line arguments into the instance variables of your program. 
     CmdLine.load(instance, args);
    Decorate your instance variables with this @Arg annotation to tell the parser what to do. Maybe something like this (to follow on the --tail example) in the MyProgram class. 
     @Arg
 private boolean tail;
    You can decorate instance variables of many types (including all primitives) and also those of any POJO as long as the POJO is decorated with the @Arg annotation. Arrays and java.util.List of these same types are also valid. For instance, you may want to allow the user of your program to specify multiple files for processing 
     @Arg
 private File[] inputFiles;
    Then the user could enter this on the command line and the inputFiles instance variable would contain the File objects. 
     >myProgram --inputFiles oneFile.txt anotherFile.txt
    Author:
    Chris DeGreef fedupforone@gmail.com
    See Also:
    Boolean, Byte, Character, String, Integer, Long, Float, Double, File, Date, Calendar, Pattern, WildFiles, Equ

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      boolean allowCamelCaps
      Indicates that the user can specify the argument on the command-line using the Camel Caps version of the long name.
      boolean allowMetaphone
      Indicates that the user can specify the argument on the command-line with misspellings as long as it evaluates to the Metaphone equivalent of the long name.
      boolean caseSensitive
      Indicates that all values associated with this argument are case sensitive.
      String[] defaultValues
      Indicates the default value(s) for this argument.
      String[] excludeArgs
      Indicates the arguments from a pojo that should be excluded from the parser.
      String factoryArgName
      Indicates the argument from an embedded parser that is to be used as a String parameter to the factory method.
      String factoryMethod
      Indicates the factory method to be used when creating an instance of this embedded parser.
      String format
      Indicates the date format for types of Date.
      String help
      Indicates the message that will be included in the usage for this argument.
      String inEnum
      Indicates an enum, implying a list of values that will be allowed for this argument.
      String[] inList
      Indicates a list of values that will be allowed for this argument.
      String instanceClass
      Indicates the class that will be used to create an object for this argument.
      String longName
      Indicates the single word, long name of this argument.
      String matches
      Indicates a verification pattern to be run against the user input before it will be accepted.
      int multimax
      Indicates the maximum allowed number of values that will be accepted for this argument.
      int multimin
      Indicates the minimum allowed number of values that will be accepted for this argument.
      boolean positional
      Indicates that a name is not allowed for this argument.
      String[] range
      Indicates a criteria to be applied to the user's input.
      boolean required
      Indicates that this argument is required - the user must provide the argument.
      char shortName
      Indicates the single character, short name of this argument.
      int uniqueId
      Indicates a non-used integer value that will be kept with the argument in internal memory.
      String variable
      Indicates that a variable in the complex class of the previous @Arg annotation (without the variable parameter) is to be annotated.

    • Field Detail

      • SELF_REFERENCING_ARGNAME

        public static final String SELF_REFERENCING_ARGNAME

    • Element Detail

      • allowCamelCaps

        public abstract boolean allowCamelCaps
        Indicates that the user can specify the argument on the command-line using the Camel Caps version of the long name.
        Default:
        false

      • allowMetaphone

        public abstract boolean allowMetaphone
        Indicates that the user can specify the argument on the command-line with misspellings as long as it evaluates to the Metaphone equivalent of the long name.
        Default:
        false

      • caseSensitive

        public abstract boolean caseSensitive
        Indicates that all values associated with this argument are case sensitive. The default for this is false meaning that all alpha characters are converted to lowercase. If upper case is needed then make this true.
        Default:
        false

      • defaultValues

        public abstract String[] defaultValues
        Indicates the default value(s) for this argument. All entries are of the String type and will be internally converted to the proper type when needed.
        Default:
        {}

      • excludeArgs

        public abstract String[] excludeArgs
        Indicates the arguments from a pojo that should be excluded from the parser.
        Default:
        {}

      • factoryArgName

        public abstract String factoryArgName
        Indicates the argument from an embedded parser that is to be used as a String parameter to the factory method. If this is not specified then the factory method will be called without an argument. Use the argument variable name (like "type") for this value.
        Default:
        ""

      • factoryMethod

        public abstract String factoryMethod
        Indicates the factory method to be used when creating an instance of this embedded parser. It should be specified as package.class.method. If an inner class is involved then use package.class$innerClass.method
        Default:
        ""

      • format

        public abstract String format
        Indicates the date format for types of Date. User entry for this argument will be parsed with this date. Use the SimpleDateFormat parameters.
        Default:
        ""

      • help

        public abstract String help
        Indicates the message that will be included in the usage for this argument.
        Default:
        ""

      • inEnum

        public abstract String inEnum
        Indicates an enum, implying a list of values that will be allowed for this argument. They will be internally converted to a list of Strings for a criteria.
        Default:
        ""

      • inList

        public abstract String[] inList
        Indicates a list of values that will be allowed for this argument. They are to be entered as an array of Strings that will be internally converted to the proper type when needed.
        Default:
        {}

      • instanceClass

        public abstract String instanceClass
        Indicates the class that will be used to create an object for this argument. This is needed when an abstract class, maybe even Object is used as the variable type. This parameter allows the specification of the actual instance class that should be used to create the instance. An example: 
         @Arg(instanceClass = "com.obdobion.argument.VariableTest$MyGroup")
 private Object testObjectGroup;
        Default:
        ""

      • longName

        public abstract String longName
        Indicates the single word, long name of this argument. The command-line use of this is a double dash (--) followed immediately by this word, or more precisely, the unique beginning of this word relative to all other arguments at this level of the parser.

        The default for the long name is the actual name of the variable. In the example below it would not be necessary to specify the long name for the confirm variable since that is the default.

        If you prefer not to have a long name at all then set this value to be an empty string.

        Examples: 

         @Arg(longName = 'confirm')
 private boolean confirm;

 @Arg(longName = 'file')
 private File inputFile;
        With the user then running the program as... 
         >myProgram --file aFile.txt --confirm
        Default:
        ""

      • matches

        public abstract String matches
        Indicates a verification pattern to be run against the user input before it will be accepted. It must match the entire input. Use Pattern to write the value for this parameter. This pattern will be applied to the toString() result on the user input. This typically only makes sense on a type of String.
        Default:
        ""

      • multimax

        public abstract int multimax
        Indicates the maximum allowed number of values that will be accepted for this argument. Useful when the type of the variable is an array or a List. The default for the parameter is the max integer.
        Default:
        0

      • multimin

        public abstract int multimin
        Indicates the minimum allowed number of values that will be accepted for this argument. Useful when the type of the variable is an array or a List. The default for the parameter is 0.
        Default:
        0

      • positional

        public abstract boolean positional
        Indicates that a name is not allowed for this argument. The user input is for this parameter is determined based on the order of the input. A way to think about this is that all of the named arguments are extracted from the user's input, and what is left is then assigned to the positional parameters. A common use for this is file name input to your program.
        Default:
        false

      • range

        public abstract String[] range
        Indicates a criteria to be applied to the user's input. This is an array of two values; the first one being the minimum and the second the maximum, they are inclusive. The second value is optional meaning that there is no maximum associated. A typical use might to allow only positive values for an integer; range = {"1"}.
        Default:
        {}

      • required

        public abstract boolean required
        Indicates that this argument is required - the user must provide the argument. A not-so-obvious use for this is the create a boolean called confirm and apply the annotation @Arg(required=true}. This will automatically require the user to enter --confirm or the parser will throw an exception.
        Default:
        false

      • shortName

        public abstract char shortName
        Indicates the single character, short name of this argument. The command-line use of this is a single dash (-) followed immediately by this character. This needs to be unique for all arguments at the same level of the parser.

        For a boolean type of argument there would be no supplied value after the -c. For any other type of instance variable the value would follow.

        Examples: 

         @Arg(shortName = 'c')
 private boolean confirm;

 @Arg(shortName = 'f')
 private File inputFile;
        With the user then running the program as... 
         >myProgram -f aFile.txt -c
        Default:
        32

      • uniqueId

        public abstract int uniqueId
        Indicates a non-used integer value that will be kept with the argument in internal memory. There is currently no use for this value except the GUI.
        Default:
        0

      • variable

        public abstract String variable
        Indicates that a variable in the complex class of the previous @Arg annotation (without the variable parameter) is to be annotated. This is needed when the embedded complex class source is not to be directly modified by annotations.
        Default:
        ""
